review.title: ERBlox: Combining Matching Dependencies with Machine Learning for Entity Resolution
review.abstract: Entity resolution (ER), an important and common data cleaning problem, is about detecting data duplicate representations for the same external entities, and merging them into single representations. Relatively recently, declarative rules called "matching dependencies" (MDs) have been proposed for specifying similarity conditions under which attribute values in database records are merged. In this work we show the process and the benefits of integrating four components of ER: (a) Building a classifier for duplicate/non-duplicate record pairs built using machine learning (ML) techniques; (b) Use of MDs for supporting the blocking phase of ML; (c) Record merging on the basis of the classifier results; and (d) The use of the declarative language "LogiQL" -an extended form of Datalog supported by the "LogicBlox" platform- for all activities related to data processing, and the specification and enforcement of MDs.
histories: Revised journal submission after acceptance with minor revisions. Extended version ofarXiv:1508.06013
Final journal version, with some minor technical corrections. Extended version ofarXiv:1508.06013

metadata.title: ERBlox: Combining Matching Dependencies with Machine Learning for Entity Resolution

sections.text: Entity resolution (ER), an important and widespread problem of data cleanup, involves recognizing duplicate data representations for the same external entities and merging them into individual representations. Relatively recently, declarative rules known as Matching Dependencies (MDs) have been proposed to set similarity conditions under which attribute values are merged into database records. In this paper, we will demonstrate the process and benefits of integrating four components of ER: (a) building a classifier for duplicate / non-duplicate record pairs that are created using machine learning (ML); (b) using MDs to support the block phase of ML; (c) recording merging based on classification results; and (d) using the LogiQL declarative language - an extended form of data catalog supported by the LogicBlox platform - for all data processing activities related to data processing and DM00 specification: Vty and Enforcement: Enforcement of DMs.2010.

sections.heading: 10. Conclusions
sections.text: We have shown that matching dependencies, a new class of semantic constraints on data quality and purification, can be profitably integrated with traditional ML methods, in our case for the development of classification models for entity resolution. These dependencies play a role not only in their intended goal of blocking the merging of duplicate representations, but also in the record-blocking process that precedes the correct learning task. At this stage, they capture declarative semantic information that can be used to enrich the blocking activity. MD's explanation and enforcement, data processing in general, and machine learning can all be integrated using the LogiQL language. In fact, all data extractions, movements, and transformation tasks are performed via LogiQL, a form of extended database supported by the LogicBlox platform. In this regard, it is interesting to mention that Datalog has existed since the early 1980s, as a declarative and rule-based language for databases.

An unsupervised clustering-based approach to collective deduplication is proposed in [12].
This approach falls in the context of relational learning [30].
More precisely, in [12], a relationship graph is built whose nodes are the entities (records), and edges indicate entities which co-occur.
Experimental results [12] show that this form of collective deduplication outperforms traditional deduplication.

The approach to ER in [12] could be seen as implicitly involving collective blocking, where relationships between entities and similarities between attribute values are used to create the blocks of records.
A comparison of our whole approach to ER with other (whole) collective approaches to ER, such as that in [12] has to be left for future research.
Dedupalog, a declarative approach to collective entity deduplication in the presence of constraints, is proposed in [2].
In [2], equality-generating dependencies were used as hard constraints, and clustering-rules as weak constraints.

metadata.abstractText: Entity resolution (ER), an important and common data cleaning problem, is about detecting data duplicate representations for the same external entities, and merging them into single representations. Relatively recently, declarative rules called matching dependencies (MDs) have been proposed for specifying similarity conditions under which attribute values in database records are merged. In this work we show the process and the benefits of integrating four components of ER: (a) Building a classifier for duplicate/non-duplicate record pairs built using machine learning (ML) techniques; (b) Use of MDs for supporting the blocking phase of ML; (c) Record merging on the basis of the classifier results; and (d) The use of the declarative language LogiQL -an extended form of Datalog supported by the LogicBlox platformfor all activities related to data processing, and the specification and enforcement of MDs.
